comments:
FNCE 250 covers the finance of technological innovation, with a focus on the valuation tools useful in the venture capital industry. These tools include the \"venture capital method,\" comparable analysis, discounted cash flow analysis, Monte Carlo simulation, contingent-claims analysis, decision trees, and real options. The targeted demographic for this course is finance majors interested in careers in venture capital or in R&D-intensive companies in health care or information technology.

Students should have a firm grasp of statistics as well as strong problem solving and analytical thinking skills before attempting FNCE 250. Some students felt that the material introduced in FNCE 250 was too academic with little relation to the real-world venture capital industry.

Many students describe Professor Taylor as “passionate,” “articulate,” and “good at easily communicating content to students.” Nonetheless, as a new professor at Wharton and without significant experience in the world of venture capital, several students felt that he was unfit to teach FNCE 250. Students argued that for a course as involved as FNCE 250, it is imperative that the professor be well-versed and experienced with the venture capital industry.

Most students find FNCE 250 highly work intensive. Students should be especially prepared for lengthy homework assignments. Some felt that there was not enough correlation between the material on homework, in lectures, and on exams.
